work.p: Phrases in this manuscript are similar to phrases that appeared in "Song of Myself." See, for instance: "It is for you whoever you are, it is no farther from you than your hearing and sight are from you, / It is hinted by nearest, commonest, readiest, it is ever provoked by them" (1891, p. 171); "I take my place among you as much as among any," (1891, p. 70); "Nor do I understand who there can be more wonderful than myself" (1891, p. 76); "What is commonest, cheapest, nearest, easiest, is Me," (1891, p. 39).

titleStmt.title: The most perfect wonders
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Based on the handwriting, Edward Grier dates this manuscript to 1855 or earlier (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 1:186). Some of the language is similar to wording in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself." An image of the verso is currently unavailable.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman

revisionDesc.change: checked; revised repository information in header

body.p: The most perfect wonders of the earth are not I rare and distant but present with every person,—you as much as any!—
tr down Man! Woman! Youth! wherever you are, in the Northern, Southern, Eastern, or Western States—in KanadaCanada—by the sea-coast, or far inland—the

Th What is more amazing than the day sun-rise, the day, the floods of light enveloping the fields, t waters, grass, trees, persons?—What is more beautiful than the night, the full moon, and the stars?—The prairies, the lakes, t rivers, forests,—all are

Not distant caverns, volcanoes, cataracts, curious islands, birds, foreign cities, architecture, costumes, markets, ceremonies, shows, are any more wonderful than ‸ what is common to you, near you now, and continually with you.—
